docs.snippet: They were huddled together on the edge of the crowd, watching with amazement as the downtown plaza slowly filled with red flags and chanting youths. Their gaunt bodies, sunken cheeks and near-shaven heads immediately identified them.     Only that...
docs.lead_paragraph: They were huddled together on the edge of the crowd, watching with amazement as the downtown plaza slowly filled with red flags and chanting youths. Their gaunt bodies, sunken cheeks and near-shaven heads immediately identified them. Only that morning, one of them, Raul Rodriguez, a 41-year-old former journalist, had been ordered, ''Get your things ready, you're off.'' He was told to sign a document testifying that he had been well treated during his 10 years in jail, but he refused. A few hours later, he and several other former Tupamaro guerrillas were freed anyway.

headline.main: FOR FREED LEFTISTS IN URUGUAY, HIDDEN TERRORS

docs.snippet: When Brazil's new civilian President takes over on Friday after 21 years of military Government, 90 percent of Latin America's inhabitants will be living under civilian rule, a situation unmatched since 1961. But President Tancredo Neves, who will...
docs.lead_paragraph: When Brazil's new civilian President takes over on Friday after 21 years of military Government, 90 percent of Latin America's inhabitants will be living under civilian rule, a situation unmatched since 1961. But President Tancredo Neves, who will receive the legacy of Brazil's vast resources, will also inherit the consequences of longstanding neglect of the country's basic needs. A succession of countries - Brazil will be the ninth - have moved from military to civilian governments since 1979, but almost without exception they have continued to live with acute economic and foreign debt crises, inflexible as well as unjust social structures and the perennial shadow of interference by the military. Most people of the continent are worse off than a few years ago, raising the question: Is democracy enough?

headline.main: PAST WEIGHS HEAVY ON LATIN DEMOCRACIES

docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Not only is Carl Mora right when he states, ''many Spanish-speaking Latin Americans have no ancestral connection at all to Spain'' (letter, Feb. 25), but in fact, the Spanish stock in the Latin American population is minute.   In...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Not only is Carl Mora right when he states, ''many Spanish-speaking Latin Americans have no ancestral connection at all to Spain'' (letter, Feb. 25), but in fact, the Spanish stock in the Latin American population is minute. In 1959, there were only four countries in Latin America in which the white population exceeded the nonwhite: Argentina, Costa Rica, Uruguay and Cuba.

docs.snippet: Civilian rule was restored in Brazil today for the first time since 1964, even though the 75-year-old President-elect underwent emergency surgery late Thursday and was unable to take the oath of office.     As Tancredo Neves, the President- elect,...
docs.lead_paragraph: Civilian rule was restored in Brazil today for the first time since 1964, even though the 75-year-old President-elect underwent emergency surgery late Thursday and was unable to take the oath of office. As Tancredo Neves, the President- elect, was recuperating, his running mate, Jose Sarney, was sworn in and designated as interim President. Mr. Sarney then swore in the 27-member Cabinet and received the heads of foreign delegations, including Vice President Bush. Doctors said Mr. Neves was recovering well from a two-hour operation for an acute intestinal inflammation known as diverticulitis. ''He should be out of the hospital in a week and be ready for work in two weeks,'' Dr. Renault Mattos, his physician, said today.

headline.main: BRAZILIAN INAUGURATION ENDS THE GENERALS' RULE

docs.snippet: In the war against crime, very few agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation go over to the other side. So it was a dispiriting occasion last week when Dan A. Mitrione Jr., a former undercover agent, pleaded guilty to taking $850,000 in bribes...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the war against crime, very few agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation go over to the other side. So it was a dispiriting occasion last week when Dan A. Mitrione Jr., a former undercover agent, pleaded guilty to taking $850,000 in bribes and payoffs from a drug ring. Mr. Mitrione also admitted in Federal court in Miami that he had ''skimmed'' and sold part of a cocaine shipment he had confiscated in Memphis. In another F.B.I. corruption case, Richard William Miller, a 20-year agency veteran in Los Angeles, is charged with spying for the Soviet Union.

headline.main: The UnmakingOf an AgentAt the F.B.I.

byline.original: By Caroline Rand Herron and Michael Wright

docs.snippet: In a cerebral celebration of St. Patrick's Day, Thomas Flanagan, a professor whose first novel, ''The Year of the French,'' won the National Book Critics Circle Award in 1980, and Seamus Heaney, the Irish poet, will share a three-day residency at...
docs.lead_paragraph: In a cerebral celebration of St. Patrick's Day, Thomas Flanagan, a professor whose first novel, ''The Year of the French,'' won the National Book Critics Circle Award in 1980, and Seamus Heaney, the Irish poet, will share a three-day residency at Seton Hall University in South Orange this week. The two men will read from their works at free programs in the Theater-in-the-Round in the Bishop Dougherty Student Center, Mr. Flanagan at 8 P.M. Wednesday and Mr. Heaney at the same time on Thursday. The presentations are called ''The Irish Literary Imaginaton.'' Although Mr. Flanagan, a scholar and critic of Irish literature, was born in Greenwich, Conn., and teaches at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, he has spent the last 30 summers in Ireland.

docs.snippet: Roberto Etchepareborda, a historian and professor who was Foreign Minister of Argentina in 1962, died of a heart attack Wednesday while walking home from a bus stop in this suburb of Washington, the Fairfax County police said. He was 62 years old.
